facts.text: These appeals are brought, by certificate, from the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, dated September 25, 1964, in Income-tax Reference No. 22 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswami, J. These appeals are brought, by certificate, from the judgment of the High Court of Gujarat, dated September 25, 1964, in Income-tax Reference No. 22 of 1963.

facts.text: Hazrat Pirmahomed Shah Saheb was a renowned Muslim saint who lived in Gujarat in the early half of the eighteenth Century.

anchor.surface_text: Hazrat Pirmahomed Shah Saheb was a renowned Muslim saint who lived in Gujarat in the early half of the eighteenth Century.

facts.text: At the time of his death he left a large number of followers.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of his death he left a large number of followers. During his lifetime he initiated some of his followers as his disciples and those so initiated came to be known as Murids.

facts.text: He died in 1742.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of the saint in 1742, his disciples and devotees subscribed moneys and collected donations for the purpose of building a Roza or Dargah mausoleum to commemorate his memory.

facts.text: During his lifetime he initiated some of his followers as his disciples and those so initiated came to be known as Murids.

anchor.surface_text: During his lifetime he initiated some of his followers as his disciples and those so initiated came to be known as Murids. At the time of the demise of the saint, the number of Murids was about 400.

facts.text: At the time of the demise of the saint, the number of Murids was about 400.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the demise of the saint, the number of Murids was about 400. The descendants of the Murids also became Murids.

facts.text: The descendants of the Murids also became Murids.

anchor.surface_text: The descendants of the Murids also became Murids. Thus the class of Murids consists of the descendants of the Murids initiated by the saint in his lifetime.

facts.text: After the death of the saint in 1742, his disciples and devotees subscribed moneys and collected donations for the purpose of building a Roza or Dargah mausoleum to commemorate his memory.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of the saint in 1742, his disciples and devotees subscribed moneys and collected donations for the purpose of building a Roza or Dargah mausoleum to commemorate his memory. Besides the Roza, a mosque was also built for the purpose of offering Fatiahs and prayers.

facts.text: Besides the Roza, a mosque was also built for the purpose of offering Fatiahs and prayers.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the Roza, a mosque was also built for the purpose of offering Fatiahs and prayers. In accordance with Islamic doctrine, all Muslims, whether Murids or non-Murids, had unrestricted access to the Roza and the mosque.

facts.text: In accordance with Islamic doctrine, all Muslims, whether Murids or non-Murids, had unrestricted access to the Roza and the mosque.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with Islamic doctrine, all Muslims, whether Murids or non-Murids, had unrestricted access to the Roza and the mosque. Now the maintenance of the Roza and the mosque required moneys and so also did the observance of festive occasions such as Urs, death anniversaries, etc., at these institutions.

facts.text: Several gifts of properties were made by Murids for maintenance of Roza, mosque, Urs etc., and properties purchased out of offerings.

anchor.surface_text: Several gifts of properties were, therefore, made by Murids for these purposes and certain properties were also purchased by persons in management out of offerings made at these institutions.

facts.text: All these properties were treated as properties of the Roza.

anchor.surface_text: All these properties were treated as properties of the Roza and the income from these properties after payment of municipal taxes, insurance premia and other out-goings in respect of the properties was utilised for maintenance of the Roza and the mosque and observance of festive occasions such as Urs, death anniversaries, etc.

facts.text: Income from properties utilised for maintenance of Roza, mosque, Urs etc. after expenses.

anchor.surface_text: and the income from these properties after payment of municipal taxes, insurance premia and other out-goings in respect of the properties was utilised for maintenance of the Roza and the mosque and observance of festive occasions such as Urs, death anniversaries, etc.

facts.text: During 1942-43 to 1956-57, surplus income utilised for madrassas, library, langar, bhandar for pilgrims.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the statement of receipts and expenditure for the years 1942-43 to 1956-57 produced before the Appellate Tribunal, which is annexure L to the statement of case, that during those years a part of the surplus income of the properties after meeting this expenditure on the maintenance of the Roza and the mosque and the observance of festive occasions such as Urs, death anniversaries, etc., was also utilised for running madrassas, library and payment of expenses on items, such as langar and bhandar for giving food to pilgrims attending the Roza and the mosque on festive occasions.

facts.text: The surplus income was at sometime utilised for the personal benefit of the Murids.

anchor.surface_text: The surplus income was at sometime utilised for the personal benefit of the Murids. The Murids, however, had two kinds of rights in the properties of the Roza.

facts.text: Earliest records from first survey 1870-1880 show Roza and mosque recognised as wakf in revenue records.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest records available are the records of the first survey operations carried out between 1870 and 1880 and they show that at that time the Roza and the mosque were recognised as wakf and were entered as such in the revenue records.

facts.text: Minutes of meeting of Murids on October 15, 1888 indicate management by general body through agents until then.

anchor.surface_text: There was no evidence to show how the properties of Roza were managed prior to 1888 but the minutes of the meeting of the Murids held on October 15, 1888, indicate that until then the management of the properties was being looked after by the general body of Murids through certain appointed agents.

facts.text: At 1888 meeting, resolutions passed, properties described as Roza's, committee appointed to manage.

anchor.surface_text: At this meeting resolutions were passed by the general body of Murids laying down certain rules in connection with the management and administration of the Roza properties. In these resolutions, the properties were described as belonging to the Roza and a committee was appointed to manage and administer the Roza properties.

facts.text: Roza Committee carried on management thereafter.

anchor.surface_text: The committee hereinafter called the Roza Committee thereafter carried on the management and administration of the Roza properties.

facts.text: Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950 came into force on January 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: While the litigation was pending, the Bombay Public Trusts Act, 1950, came into force on January 21, 1952.

facts.text: Roza Committee applied for registration on May 30, 1952 under protest.

anchor.surface_text: Since the Act required applications to be made for registration of all public trusts, the Roza Committee made an application to the Charity Commissioner on May 30, 1952, for registration of the wakf.

facts.text: Application withdrawn on November 2, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The application was, however, withdrawn on November 2, 1953.

facts.text: Another application on April 28, 1955, conceded public benefit, registered April 29, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: before this inquiry was concluded, the Roza Committee made another application for registration of the wakf to the Charity Commissioner on April 28, 1955. In this application the Roza Committee conceded that the wakf was for the benefit of the public and was, therefore, liable to be registered as a public trust. The Assistant Charity Commissioner thereupon made an order dated April 29, 1955, registering the wakf as a public trust.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notices on March 28, 1953 for assessment years 1944-45 to 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, on March 28, 1953, the Income-tax Officer issued notices to the Roza Committee under section 44(1)(a) for the assessment years 1944-45 to 1948-49, the corresponding accounting years being Samvat years 1999 to 2003.

facts.text: Appellant contended income exempt under section 4(3)(i) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that the income derived from the Roza properties was exempt from tax under section 4(3)(i) of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal held wakf for private religious purpose, not public or charitable.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held, in the first place, that the Roza properties were wakf properties were held under a legal obligation for a private religious purpose and not for a public religious purpose. The Tribunal also examined the question whether the properties were held by the Roza Committee for a charitable purpose and took the view that the class of Murids could not be regarded as a section of the community and, therefore, the Roza properties were not held under a legal obligation for a wholly charitable purpose.

facts.text: High Court answered questions against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered both the questions against the appellant, holding that, upon the evidence given, the purpose of the wakf included the maintenance of madrases and the library which was not proved to be a wholly religious purpose.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Roza properties held for wholly religious purpose of public character, exempt under s.4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: Upon the facts found by the Appellate Tribunal we are of opinion that the Roza properties were held for a wholly religious purpose of a public character and therefore the income of the Roza properties was exempt from assessment under section 4(3)(i) of the Act.

facts.text: No evidence of utilisation for madrassas or library prior to 1942-43.

anchor.surface_text: There was, however, no evidence before the Appellate Tribunal to show that any portion of the income of the wakf was utilised for madrassas or library prior to the year 1942-43.

facts.text: Original purpose confined to maintenance of Roza, mosque, festive occasions.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal therefore held that the original purpose of the wakf was confined to the maintenance of the Roza and the mosque and celebration of festive occasions and therefore the wakf was established for a wholly religious purpose.

Section 4(3)(i) of the Act, as it stood at the material time, was to the following effect 4.  3  Any income, profits or gains falling within the following classes shall number be included in the total income of the person receiving them Any income derived from property held under trust or other legal obligation wholly for religious or charitable purposes, and in the case of property so held in part only for such purposes, the income applied, or finally set apart for application, thereto In this sub-section charitable purpose includes relief of the poor, education, medical relief, and the advancement of any other object of general public utility, but numberhing companytained in clause  i , clause  ia  or clause  ii  shall operate to exempt from the provisions of this Act that part of the income of a private religious trust which does number ensure for the benefit of the public.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the properties of the Hazrat Pir Mohamed Shah Saheb Roza Committee are held under trust or other legal obligation for public, religious or charitable object?

anchor.surface_text: As directed by the High Court, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case on the following questions of law Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the properties of the Hazrat Pir Mohamed Shah Saheb Roza Committee are held under trust or other legal obligation for public, religious or charitable object ?

issues.text: Whether the income from the wakf properties for the relevant assessment years is entitled to exemption under section 4(3)(i) and/or 4(3)(ii) of the Indian Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the income from the wakf properties for the relevant assessment years is entitled to exemption under section 4 3  i  and or 4 3  ii  of the Indian Income-tax Ac ? issues.text: whether the Roza properties were held in trust or under a legal obligation wholly for a religious purpose

anchor.surface_text: The main question presented for determination in these appeals is whether the Roza properties were held in trust or under a legal obligation wholly for a religious purpose. The Appellate Tribunal elaborately examined this question and found that the wakf was for a wholly religious purpose.

issues.text: whether the High Court had justification for interfering with the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the wakf was wholly for a religious purpose

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to what was the object of the wakf is essentially a question of fact and the High Court had, therefore, no justification for interfering with the finding of the Tribunal on this point.

arguments.claim: Roza properties held wholly for religious purpose of public character; income exempt u/s 4(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated by the Appellate Tribunal that the benefit of the wakf was available to all Muslims whether Murids or non-Murids who had unrestricted access to the Roza and mosque and the festivities celebrated therein. Upon the facts found by the Appellate Tribunal we are of opinion that the Roza properties were held for a wholly religious purpose of a public character and therefore the income of the Roza properties was exempt from assessment under section 4(3)(i) of the Act.

arguments.claim: Class of Murids constituted appreciable section of Sunni Bohra community; wholly charitable purpose.
arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as religious ground sufficient.

arguments.claim: Class of Murids did not constitute section of community but fluctuating body of private individuals.
Oppenheim case analogous: nexus too narrow for public benefit.
Wakf not for public benefit but merely for benefit of Murids; not public trust (initial contention).

anchor.surface_text: The application was made under protest since the contention of the Roza Committee was that the wakf was not a wakf for the benefit of the public but was a wakf merely for the benefit of the Murids and was, therefore, not liable to be registered as a public trust.

holdings.text: the Roza properties were held for a wholly religious purpose of a public character and therefore the income of the Roza properties was exempt from assessment under section 4(3)(i) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Upon the facts found by the Appellate Tribunal we are of opinion that the Roza properties were held for a wholly religious purpose of a public character and therefore the income of the Roza properties was exempt from assessment under section 4(3)(i) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal findings show unrestricted access to all Muslims per Islamic doctrine, original purpose maintenance of Roza, mosque, Urs; qualifies as public religious purpose under s.4(3)(i)

holdings.text: the question as to what was the object of the wakf is essentially a question of fact and the High Court had, therefore, no justification for interfering with the finding of the Tribunal on this point

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to what was the object of the wakf is essentially a question of fact and the High Court had, therefore, no justification for interfering with the finding of the Tribunal on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wakf object determination is factual; HC in s.66 reference bound by Tribunal findings absent s.66(1) challenge

holdings.text: there was no warrant for the High Court to interfere with the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the purpose of the wakf was wholly religious and the maintenance of madrassas and library from 1942-43 onwards was not the original purpose

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we think that there was no warrant for the High Court to interfere within the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the purpose of the wakf was wholly religious and the maintenance of madrassas and library from 1942-43 onwards was not the original purpose for which the properties were gifted by the Murids,

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of madrassa/library use pre-1942-43; later surplus use does not alter original wholly religious character

holdings.text: in a reference under section 66 of the Act the High Court must accept the findings of fact made by the Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in India Cements Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax that in a reference under section 66 of the Act the High Court must accept the findings of fact made by the Appellate Tribunal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: HC not appellate authority; cannot reassess facts without prior s.66(1) application challenging them

holdings.text: the questions referred to the High Court must be answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the High Court should be set aside and the questions referred to the High Court must be answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

holdings.text: it is not necessary to express any concluded opinion on [charitable purpose aspect]
holdings.reasoning_summary: Religious purpose ground sufficient; alternative charitable argument obiter

precedents.citation: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: class of persons defined by employment nexus does not constitute a section of the community for charitable trust public benefit test

precedents.citation: India Cements Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: India Cements Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

precedents.case_name: India Cements Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: in income tax reference under section 66, High Court must accept findings of fact by Appellate Tribunal and cannot reopen them unless specifically challenged
precedents.cited_holding: in a reference under section 66 of the Act the High Court must accept the findings of fact made by the Appellate Tribunal, and it is not open to the High Court to reopen the findings of fact unless the party concerned has applied for a reference to challenge those findings first by an application under section 66(1) of the Act

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. M.Ganapathi Mudaliar

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. M.Ganapathi Mudaliar

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. M.Ganapathi Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court cannot act as appellate court in reviewing Tribunal's findings of fact even on existence of material
precedents.cited_holding: even if the question referred to the High Court is regarding the existence of material to support a finding of fact arrived at by the Appellate Tribunal, the High Court should not act as an appellate court and consider whether the finding was justified or not

precedents.citation: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.

precedents.case_name: Oppenheim v. Tobacco Securities Trust Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: trust for employees of particular employers, though numerous, does not satisfy public benefit test for charity due to common nexus
precedents.cited_holding: though the group of persons indicated was numerous, the nexus between them was employment by particular employers, and accordingly the trust did not satisfy the test of public benefit requisite to establish it as charitable

precedents.citation: Mohamed Falil Abdul Gaffoor and Others Trustees of the Abdul Caffoor Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Colombo

anchor.surface_text: Mohamed Falil Abdul Gaffoor and Others Trustees of the Abdul Caffoor Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Colombo

precedents.case_name: Mohamed Falil Abdul Gaffoor and Others, Trustees of the Abdul Caffoor Trust v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Colombo
precedents.cited_proposition: trust giving absolute priority to grantor's family is private family trust, not public charitable trust
precedents.cited_holding: in view of the absolute priority to the benefit of the trust income which was conferred on the grantors own family by clause (2)(b)(i) of the trust deed, this was a family trust and not a trust of a public character wholly for charitable purpose, and income thereof was accordingly not entitled to the exemption claimed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the High Court should be set aside and the questions referred to the High Court must be answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. We accordingly allow these appeals with c

outcome.relief_summary: Judgment of the High Court set aside; questions answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee; income exempt under section 4(3)(i)
directions: judgment of the High Court set aside

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the question as to what was the object of the wakf is essentially a question of fact and the High Court had, therefore, no justification for interfering with the finding of the Tribunal on this point.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we think that there was no warrant for the High Court to interfere within the finding of the Appellate Tribunal that the purpose of the wakf was wholly religious and the maintenance of madrassas and library from 1942-43 onwards was not the original purpose for which the properties were gifted by the Murids,

For these reasons we hold that the judgment of the High Court should be set aside and the questions referred to the High Court must be answered in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. We accordingly allow these appeals with c
